linkedinOrgTeaser:
The marketing playbook is flipping in 2026.

Omnicom's Pinterest partnership reveals a critical shift: intent-based marketing is outperforming impression-based strategies by significant margins.

Meanwhile, Figs is proving that community infrastructure beats paid acquisition - their "Community Hubs" convert 40% of visitors to new customers.

As AI agents mediate more purchase decisions, brands lacking differentiation risk algorithmic exclusion entirely.

The winners are engineering relevance, not chasing reach.

linkedinPersonalTeaser:
Something interesting is happening in marketing right now.

For decades, the game was maximize reach, optimize impressions, pray for conversions. But that formula is breaking down.

The Omnicom-Pinterest deal announced at CES buried the lede: intent beats impressions. Figs is building stores in medical districts instead of malls. And AI is quietly restructuring how purchase decisions get made.

Brands still optimizing for reach will wake up one morning to discover their customers are making decisions in places they never thought to show up.

What's your take - is reach-based marketing actually dying, or just evolving?
